subject: Add DNS support
message:
Add DNS support

On 04 Oct 2008 Pieter posted a dns implementation for U-Boot.

http://www.mail-archive.com/u-boot-users@lists.sourceforge.net/msg10216.html
>
> DNS can be enabled by setting CFG_CMD_DNS. After performing a query,
> the serverip environment var is updated.
>
> Probably there are some cosmetic issues with the patch. Unfortunatly I
> do not have the time to correct these. So if anybody else likes DNS
> support in U-Boot and has the time, feel free to patch it in the main tree.

Here it is again - slightly modified & smaller:
  - update to 2009-06 (Pieter's patch was for U-Boot 1.2.0)
  - README.dns is added
  - syntax is changed (now takes a third option, the env var to store
    the result in)
  - add a random port() function in net.c
  - sort Makefile in ./net/Makefile
  - dns just returns unless a env var is given
  - run through checkpatch, and clean up style issues
  - remove packet from stack
  - cleaned up some comments
  - failure returns much faster (if server responds, don't wait for
    timeout)
  - use built in functions (memcpy) rather than byte copy.

Signed-off-by: Robin Getz <e9953c06f5600a6961c280ee2983a53290f44eef@blackfin.uclinux.org>
Signed-off-by: Pieter Voorthuijsen <e0cadd18c4900fc6b932d59ce7e1ebde5dd654eb@prodrive.nl>
Signed-off-by: Ben Warren <d04a705be7c1a37a14da27b05574785fa8b6469d@gmail.com>
message_without_subject:
On 04 Oct 2008 Pieter posted a dns implementation for U-Boot.

http://www.mail-archive.com/u-boot-users@lists.sourceforge.net/msg10216.html
>
> DNS can be enabled by setting CFG_CMD_DNS. After performing a query,
> the serverip environment var is updated.
>
> Probably there are some cosmetic issues with the patch. Unfortunatly I
> do not have the time to correct these. So if anybody else likes DNS
> support in U-Boot and has the time, feel free to patch it in the main tree.

Here it is again - slightly modified & smaller:
  - update to 2009-06 (Pieter's patch was for U-Boot 1.2.0)
  - README.dns is added
  - syntax is changed (now takes a third option, the env var to store
    the result in)
  - add a random port() function in net.c
  - sort Makefile in ./net/Makefile
  - dns just returns unless a env var is given
  - run through checkpatch, and clean up style issues
  - remove packet from stack
  - cleaned up some comments
  - failure returns much faster (if server responds, don't wait for
    timeout)
  - use built in functions (memcpy) rather than byte copy.

Signed-off-by: Robin Getz <e9953c06f5600a6961c280ee2983a53290f44eef@blackfin.uclinux.org>

subject: sunxi: Enable ALDO3 and ALDO4 in Wobo_i5_defconfig
message:
sunxi: Enable ALDO3 and ALDO4 in Wobo_i5_defconfig

These are used for the usb wifi and if we leave the enabling up to the
kernel, we get hit by the axp209 issues with enabling ldo3 or 4 post boot
and the systems hangs as soon as it is enabled.

subject: checkpatch.pl: Make fdt / initrd relocation disabling an error
message:
checkpatch.pl: Make fdt / initrd relocation disabling an error

Entirely disabling relocation of the device tree or initrd is almost
never the right answer.  Doing this by default leads to hard to diagnose
run-time failures.

Signed-off-by: Tom Rini <47764aff062bf9ebe98a2274b29052b74a9567e2@konsulko.com>
message_without_subject:
Entirely disabling relocation of the device tree or initrd is almost
never the right answer.  Doing this by default leads to hard to diagnose
run-time failures.

subject: net, davinci_emac: let the EMAC detect the PHYs
message:
net, davinci_emac: let the EMAC detect the PHYs

Once the MDIO state machine has been initialized and enabled, it
starts polling all 32 PHY addresses on the MDIO bus, looking for
an active PHY. Add a 5 ms delay, so all PHYs are for sure detected.

This problem was detected on the cmc board with a KSZ8864 switch.

Signed-off-by: Heiko Schocher <6a253031d5fc83cdcd7910737760a89b7bcfb849@denx.de>
Signed-off-by: Sandeep Paulraj <6de3c446777fc4f97162840abbd07b57207b01cc@ti.com>
message_without_subject:
Once the MDIO state machine has been initialized and enabled, it
starts polling all 32 PHY addresses on the MDIO bus, looking for
an active PHY. Add a 5 ms delay, so all PHYs are for sure detected.

This problem was detected on the cmc board with a KSZ8864 switch.

Signed-off-by: Heiko Schocher <6a253031d5fc83cdcd7910737760a89b7bcfb849@denx.de>
Signed-off-by: Sandeep Paulraj <6de3c446777fc4f97162840abbd07b57207b01cc@ti.com>

subject: nand_spl: Fix cmd_ctrl usage in nand_boot.c.
message:
nand_spl: Fix cmd_ctrl usage in nand_boot.c.

When adding large page NAND support to this file, I had a misunderstanding
about the exact semantics of NAND_CTRL_CHANGE (which isn't documented
anywhere I can find) -- it is apparently just a hint to drivers,
which aren't required to preserve the old value for subsequent
non-"change" invocations.

This change makes nand_boot.c no longer assume this.  Note that this
happened to work by chance with some NAND drivers, which don't preserve
the value, but treat 0 equivalently to NAND_CTRL_ALE.

I don't have hardware to test this, so any testing is appreciated.

Signed-off-by: Scott Wood <b77916c2feab81a70245e7b5671f4f02730ebf64@freescale.com>
message_without_subject:
When adding large page NAND support to this file, I had a misunderstanding
about the exact semantics of NAND_CTRL_CHANGE (which isn't documented
anywhere I can find) -- it is apparently just a hint to drivers,
which aren't required to preserve the old value for subsequent
non-"change" invocations.

This change makes nand_boot.c no longer assume this.  Note that this
happened to work by chance with some NAND drivers, which don't preserve
the value, but treat 0 equivalently to NAND_CTRL_ALE.

I don't have hardware to test this, so any testing is appreciated.

Signed-off-by: Scott Wood <b77916c2feab81a70245e7b5671f4f02730ebf64@freescale.com>

subject: mpc8569mds: fix CONFIG_ENV_SIZE
message:
mpc8569mds: fix CONFIG_ENV_SIZE

CONFIG_ENV_SIZE of MPC8569MDS was wrongly set to CONFIG_ENV_SECT_SIZE which
is 128KB, so it took longer time to do crc32 calculation for ENV than it should
do. It causes the bootup for MPC8569MDS significantly slow. This patch fixs it
to 0x2000(8KB), also fix the comment for CONFIG_ENV_SECT_SIZE to correct size.

Signed-off-by: Kai.Jiang <Kai.Jiang@freescale.com
Signed-off-by: Haiying Wang <ad99e7d0da1e630b242bd730eaab4a2546837e29@freescale.com>
Signed-off-by: Kumar Gala <383ef5577c6e1178b93f59ec8d0936f76d2a98c4@kernel.crashing.org>
message_without_subject:
CONFIG_ENV_SIZE of MPC8569MDS was wrongly set to CONFIG_ENV_SECT_SIZE which
is 128KB, so it took longer time to do crc32 calculation for ENV than it should
do. It causes the bootup for MPC8569MDS significantly slow. This patch fixs it
to 0x2000(8KB), also fix the comment for CONFIG_ENV_SECT_SIZE to correct size.

Signed-off-by: Kai.Jiang <Kai.Jiang@freescale.com

subject: powerpc/85xx: verify the current address of CCSR before relocating it
message:
powerpc/85xx: verify the current address of CCSR before relocating it

Verify that CCSR is actually located where it is supposed to be before
we relocate it.  This is useful in detecting U-Boot configurations that
are broken (e.g. an incorrect value for CONFIG_SYS_CCSRBAR_DEFAULT).
If the current value is wrong, we enter an infinite loop, which is handy
for debuggers.

Signed-off-by: Timur Tabi <4ea348ebd818e67772cb0086d44dc1b57ba54129@freescale.com>
Signed-off-by: Kumar Gala <383ef5577c6e1178b93f59ec8d0936f76d2a98c4@kernel.crashing.org>
message_without_subject:
Verify that CCSR is actually located where it is supposed to be before
we relocate it.  This is useful in detecting U-Boot configurations that
are broken (e.g. an incorrect value for CONFIG_SYS_CCSRBAR_DEFAULT).
If the current value is wrong, we enter an infinite loop, which is handy
for debuggers.

subject: common/lcd: Add command for writing to lcd-display
message:
common/lcd: Add command for writing to lcd-display

Sometimes we do not want redirect u-boot's console to screen but anyway we want
write out some status information out of a u-boot script to the display.

So we cannot use the normal "echo ....", instead we write explicitly using
"lcdputs ..." for writing to the actual cursor position on LCD.

Signed-off-by: Hannes Petermaier <7657d59c56274be36a025570f1176fae6f7571c3@oevsv.at>
message_without_subject:
Sometimes we do not want redirect u-boot's console to screen but anyway we want
write out some status information out of a u-boot script to the display.

So we cannot use the normal "echo ....", instead we write explicitly using
"lcdputs ..." for writing to the actual cursor position on LCD.

subject: usb: dwc3: gadget: add common endpoint configuration for dwc3 udc driver
message:
usb: dwc3: gadget: add common endpoint configuration for dwc3 udc driver

This patch adds code to select standard, commonly used usb endpoint
configuration (ep1in-bulk, ep2out-bulk, ep3in-int) to dwc3 driver. This
ensures compatibility with old userspace and windows drivers, which
expects hardcoded endpoint numbers.

subject: wallet: use relay fee to check for dust not fee rate
message:
wallet: use relay fee to check for dust not fee rate

In this commit we fix a lingering bug in our output sanity checks that
would only show up during time periods of persistently higher fees.
Before this commit we would incorrectly use the fee rate instead of the
min relay fee when checking an output for dust. This would cause us to
mistakenly reject a transaction for having a dust output.

We fix this by falling back to using the current min-relayfee.
message_without_subject:
In this commit we fix a lingering bug in our output sanity checks that
would only show up during time periods of persistently higher fees.
Before this commit we would incorrectly use the fee rate instead of the
min relay fee when checking an output for dust. This would cause us to
mistakenly reject a transaction for having a dust output.

We fix this by falling back to using the current min-relayfee.

subject: Fix scrolling after delete from reconcile buffer
message:
Fix scrolling after delete from reconcile buffer

After a delete (keyboard shortcut 'd') from *reconcile* buffer,
the *ledger* buffer is scrolled to *first* transaction of reconcile
buffer. This fix makes that ledger buffer is scrolled to *current*
transaction from *reconcile* buffer.

the *ledger* buffer is scrolled to *first* transaction of reconcile
buffer. This fix makes that ledger buffer is scrolled to *current*
transaction from *reconcile* buffer.

subject: 1. Juick. 1.0. Продолжение доработки нововведений ревизий r605 и r606. 1.1. Переключалка главного Juick-контакта переехала в отдельное меню. Переключалка появляется только в том случае, если в ростере на данный момент 2 или более Juick-контактов и отвечает за главный Juick-контакт текущего подключённого аккаунта. 1.2. Теперь при наборе сообщения в редакторе, вызванном через команду "[J] Сущности" (в не Juick контакте) или по # (JuBo), по команде "Отмена"/"Отложить" Вы будете перемещены *назад*, а не в список сообщений главного Juick-контакта. 1.3. В пользовательские сочетания клавиш добавлена команда "Juick (Фокус и Команды)". По этому сочетанию в ростере фокус установится на (главном) Juick-контакте. В списке сообщений выведется на экран список "Команд Juick".
message:
1. Juick.
1.0. Продолжение доработки нововведений ревизий r605 и r606.
1.1. Переключалка главного Juick-контакта переехала в отдельное меню. Переключалка появляется только в том случае, если в ростере на данный момент 2 или более Juick-контактов и отвечает за главный Juick-контакт текущего подключённого аккаунта.
1.2. Теперь при наборе сообщения в редакторе, вызванном через команду "[J] Сущности" (в не Juick контакте) или по # (JuBo), по команде "Отмена"/"Отложить" Вы будете перемещены *назад*, а не в список сообщений главного Juick-контакта.
1.3. В пользовательские сочетания клавиш добавлена команда "Juick (Фокус и Команды)". По этому сочетанию в ростере фокус установится на (главном) Juick-контакте. В списке сообщений выведется на экран список "Команд Juick".

2. Разное.
2.1. Исправил баг с "зелёной кнопкой" (а также командой "Редактировать" в меню ростера) и LAST_MESSAGES. Теперь сообщение редактируеся с первого раза. Баг также иногда проявлялся в том, что по команде "[J] Сущности" выкидывало прямиком в Juick-contact.
2.2. Ввиду 1.2 добавил в редактор сообщений команду для того, чтобы послать сообщение и не переходить в список сообщений того контакта, которому послали сообщение. Появляется при попытке послать сообщение НЕ тому контакту, который открыт в текущий момент.
2.3. Вылетал с ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException при удалении самой нижней записи в архиве.
2.4. Доперевёл недопереведённое.
2.5. HistoryReader теперь читает с последних сообщений.
message_without_subject:
2. Разное.
2.1. Исправил баг с "зелёной кнопкой" (а также командой "Редактировать" в меню ростера) и LAST_MESSAGES. Теперь сообщение редактируеся с первого раза. Баг также иногда проявлялся в том, что по команде "[J] Сущности" выкидывало прямиком в Juick-contact.
2.2. Ввиду 1.2 добавил в редактор сообщений команду для того, чтобы послать сообщение и не переходить в список сообщений того контакта, которому послали сообщение. Появляется при попытке послать сообщение НЕ тому контакту, который открыт в текущий момент.
2.3. Вылетал с ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException при удалении самой нижней записи в архиве.
2.4. Доперевёл недопереведённое.
2.5. HistoryReader теперь читает с последних сообщений.

subject: fix bugs and extend coverage of redis package (#1456)
message:
fix bugs and extend coverage of redis package (#1456)

* fix bugs and extend coverage of redis package

The module exports `RedisClient`, not `Client`:

```js
> require('redis')
{ debug_mode: false,
  createClient: [Function],
  RedisClient: 
   { [Function: RedisClient]
     super_: 
      { [Function: EventEmitter]
        EventEmitter: [Circular],
        usingDomains: true,
        defaultMaxListeners: [Getter/Setter],
        init: [Function],
        listenerCount: [Function] },
     connection_id: 0 },
  print: [Function: print],
  Multi: [Function: Multi],
  AbortError: { [Function: AbortError] super_: { [Function: RedisError] super_: [Object] } },
  RedisError: 
   { [Function: RedisError]
     super_: 
      { [Function: Error]
        captureStackTrace: [Function: captureStackTrace],
        stackTraceLimit: 10 } },
  ParserError: 
   { [Function: RedisError]
     super_: 
      { [Function: Error]
        captureStackTrace: [Function: captureStackTrace],
        stackTraceLimit: 10 } },
  ReplyError: { [Function: ReplyError] super_: { [Function: RedisError] super_: [Object] } },
  AggregateError: { [Function: AggregateError] super_: { [Function: AbortError] super_: [Object] } },
  add_command: [Function: addCommand],
  addCommand: [Function: addCommand] }
```

* Update test_redis_v2.x.x.js

subject: SECURITY fix: ARITHCMD: don't test a potentially existing command
message:
SECURITY fix: ARITHCMD: don't test a potentially existing command

libexec/modernish/cap/ARITHCMD.t:
- The feature testing method created a security hole. By testing if
  the arithmetic command ((_Msh_test/=5)) succeeds, someone could
  create a command '=5' in a directory '_Msh_test' in the current
  working directory, and shells without the arithmetic command
  capability would execute it with the privileges of the script.

  FIX: use an arithmetic expression with a number enclosed in
  parentheses, so it throws a shell syntax error on shells without
  the capability. Test by eval'ing it in a subshell.
message_without_subject:
libexec/modernish/cap/ARITHCMD.t:
- The feature testing method created a security hole. By testing if
  the arithmetic command ((_Msh_test/=5)) succeeds, someone could
  create a command '=5' in a directory '_Msh_test' in the current
  working directory, and shells without the arithmetic command
  capability would execute it with the privileges of the script.

  FIX: use an arithmetic expression with a number enclosed in
  parentheses, so it throws a shell syntax error on shells without
  the capability. Test by eval'ing it in a subshell.

subject: trap stack: no longer ignore signals trapped by 'pushtrap' and not 'trap'
message:
trap stack: no longer ignore signals trapped by 'pushtrap' and not 'trap'

Traps set with 'pushtrap' have to work a bit differently if they are not to
interfere with each other, as well as with the POSIX 'trap' command (which
was intercepted to play nice with the trap stack, emulating POSIX
behaviour).

Before this commit, using 'pushtrap' with a real signal (i.e. not EXIT)
would cause that signal to be handled and then ignored, as a builtin system
trap was set to handle it and that's what 'trap' normally does. Even using
the emulated POSIX command 'trap - SIGNAL' to deactivate that trap would
still not cause the signal to stop being ignored. This made the trap stack
incompatible with normal POSIX trap operation.

This commit should fix that. If there are only stack traps and no POSIX trap
for a particular signal, then the stack traps are executed, the signal is
un-ignored (i.e. the system trap is unset), and a 'kill' is sent to self
("$$") to kill the program using the expected signal. This ought to make the
emulated 'trap' command behave exactly as expected while still playing nice
with the trap stack.

  [Note: Traps set with 'pushtrap' should never exit the shell, because the
   whole point of them is that they shouldn't interfere with each other.
   Since modernish modules can use 'pushtrap' to clean up after themselves,
   you don't necessarily know what other traps are pushed.]
message_without_subject:

was intercepted to play nice with the trap stack, emulating POSIX
behaviour).

Before this commit, using 'pushtrap' with a real signal (i.e. not EXIT)
would cause that signal to be handled and then ignored, as a builtin system
trap was set to handle it and that's what 'trap' normally does. Even using
the emulated POSIX command 'trap - SIGNAL' to deactivate that trap would
still not cause the signal to stop being ignored. This made the trap stack
incompatible with normal POSIX trap operation.

This commit should fix that. If there are only stack traps and no POSIX trap
for a particular signal, then the stack traps are executed, the signal is
un-ignored (i.e. the system trap is unset), and a 'kill' is sent to self
("$$") to kill the program using the expected signal. This ought to make the
emulated 'trap' command behave exactly as expected while still playing nice
with the trap stack.

  [Note: Traps set with 'pushtrap' should never exit the shell, because the
   whole point of them is that they shouldn't interfere with each other.
   Since modernish modules can use 'pushtrap' to clean up after themselves,
   you don't necessarily know what other traps are pushed.]

subject: die() et al: use 128, not 125, for non-signal fatal error status
message:
die() et al: use 128, not 125, for non-signal fatal error status

The die() function used exit status 125 (one lower than 126, "can't
execute") for the current process if it doesn't SIGKILL it. However
upon re-reading POSIX, I'm noticing that, although 126 and 127 and
>128 are reserved for special purposes, 128 itself is not.

I also noticed Git uses 128 for fatal error. This works well with
the default trace() hardening recipe which kills the program if the
traced/hardened command has an exit status of 126 or higher.

Statuses starting from 129 correspond to termination by a signal,
that is, the signal number + 128. Signals start at 1. That makes
128 the logical choice for "non-signal fatal error" as (a) it
corresponds to pseudosignal 0, the EXIT trap in the shell, and
(b) in binary, it is the first number with the eighth bit set.

References:
http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/utilities/V3_chap02.html#tag_18_21_18
http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/utilities/V3_chap02.html#tag_18_08_02

bin/modernish:
- die(): non-interactive: unless using signal, exit 128 (not 125)
- die(): interactive: if SIGINT is ignored, return 128 (not 125)
- _Msh_doTraps(): interactive: SIGINT handling: idem

install.sh, uninstall.sh:
- exit 128, not 125, on failure to find a good POSIX shell

libexec/modernish/var/loop.mm:
- _loop_die(): exit loop generator with status 128, not 125
message_without_subject:
The die() function used exit status 125 (one lower than 126, "can't
execute") for the current process if it doesn't SIGKILL it. However
upon re-reading POSIX, I'm noticing that, although 126 and 127 and
>128 are reserved for special purposes, 128 itself is not.

I also noticed Git uses 128 for fatal error. This works well with
the default trace() hardening recipe which kills the program if the
traced/hardened command has an exit status of 126 or higher.

Statuses starting from 129 correspond to termination by a signal,
that is, the signal number + 128. Signals start at 1. That makes
128 the logical choice for "non-signal fatal error" as (a) it
corresponds to pseudosignal 0, the EXIT trap in the shell, and
(b) in binary, it is the first number with the eighth bit set.

References:
http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/utilities/V3_chap02.html#tag_18_21_18
http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/utilities/V3_chap02.html#tag_18_08_02

bin/modernish:
- die(): non-interactive: unless using signal, exit 128 (not 125)
- die(): interactive: if SIGINT is ignored, return 128 (not 125)
- _Msh_doTraps(): interactive: SIGINT handling: idem

- exit 128, not 125, on failure to find a good POSIX shell

libexec/modernish/var/loop.mm:
- _loop_die(): exit loop generator with status 128, not 125

subject: Ghosts can start CTF on their own
message:
Ghosts can start CTF on their own

:cl: coiax
add: If enough people vote to start CTF (by clicking on a CTF controller
as a ghost), then CTF will automatically begin.
/:cl:

- CTF will no longer restart 30 seconds after it ends, it requires
people to vote for it.
- Victory messages are coloured with the team's colour.
- Current number of people required to start CTF is 4 people.

subject: Add all artefacts to group quota calc (bug #854427)
message:
Add all artefacts to group quota calc (bug #854427)

The individual quota check was including the video and audio types
but the group quota wasn't. This wasn't ideal. The quota checks
now use the PluginArtefactFile::get_artefact_types() method to make
sure this doesn't happen so easily in the future.

subject: use `var native_reduceRight` etc. variables instead of `Native = { reduceRight: ... }`
message:
use `var native_reduceRight` etc. variables instead of `Native = { reduceRight: ... }`

This way we only get the native versions of functions we use.
Will make testing non-native versions as we can't just swap do `_.Native = {}`,
but this wouldn't have worked for `isArray` and `keys` anyways, as these are
looked up on initialization, so I think the solution is to have an init()
method on underscore where we will re-initialize functions and try and use
native versions then
message_without_subject:

Will make testing non-native versions as we can't just swap do `_.Native = {}`,
but this wouldn't have worked for `isArray` and `keys` anyways, as these are
looked up on initialization, so I think the solution is to have an init()
method on underscore where we will re-initialize functions and try and use
native versions then

Fixes https://github.com/vector-im/vector-web/issues/1330

subject: Reorder AWS CLI arguments
message:
Reorder AWS CLI arguments

Move the `--sse` argument to `aws s3 cp` to the end of the command
(after the positional args).

Reason: the `--sse` option in newer versions of the AWS CLI accept an
optional encryption type. This means it must be given at the end of the
argument list, as there would be an ambiguity between the encryption
type and the positional argument that followed (the source file for the
copy, in this case).
message_without_subject:
Move the `--sse` argument to `aws s3 cp` to the end of the command
(after the positional args).

Reason: the `--sse` option in newer versions of the AWS CLI accept an
optional encryption type. This means it must be given at the end of the
argument list, as there would be an ambiguity between the encryption
type and the positional argument that followed (the source file for the
copy, in this case).

subject: Add govuk::apps::mapit class
message:
Add govuk::apps::mapit class

We're moving to deploying MapIt as a normal application. This change follows
on from acaa35f14fcba1bc65a9c987ba34b240890b96d2 which added a new machine for
mapit which will run in parallel with the existing mapit-server-* machines
until we've finished the migration.

Port 3108 has already been reserved in the development repo for MapIt:

    https://github.gds/gds/development/commit/e7587351f1fed1800872b036ffa467054aa26f9e

We're defining the database in the same class as the application config
because MapIt's database is on the same machine as the app. For most apps the
database needs to be created on a different machine from the application
config so needs to be in a separate class.

MapIt is a Python/Django app so the app type is 'procfile'. We'll add a
Procfile to our fork of the application repo.

We're moving to deploying MapIt as a normal application. This change follows
on from acaa35f14fcba1bc65a9c987ba34b240890b96d2 which added a new machine for

until we've finished the migration.

Port 3108 has already been reserved in the development repo for MapIt:

    https://github.gds/gds/development/commit/e7587351f1fed1800872b036ffa467054aa26f9e

We're defining the database in the same class as the application config
because MapIt's database is on the same machine as the app. For most apps the

MapIt is a Python/Django app so the app type is 'procfile'. We'll add a

subject: Correctly docs.publishing.service.gov.uk to docs S3
message:
Correctly docs.publishing.service.gov.uk to docs S3

In https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-puppet/pull/5269 I introduced a
nginx config to proxy docs.publishing.service.gov.uk to an S3 bucket.
The configuration was wrong, which caused nginx to crash loop on the
load balancers. Sad! The crash was fixed in
https://github.com/alphagov/govuk-puppet/pull/5279.

This time, I have employed a novel development technique called
"testing your stuff locally" to make sure that this config actually
works.

This commit fixes the following:

- By default, the nginx configs puts a HTTP basic auth password on the
proxy. We like the domain to be publicly accessible, so we disable this.
- To make S3 respond with the correct content, we set the `Hostname`
HTTP header to the name of the bucket. If this isn't set, Amazon will
try to find a bucket called `docs.publishing.service.gov.uk` and return
404.
- Add `docs` to the hostnames. This will make nginx respond on the new
`docs.x` domain.

I tested it by doing the following. First, start a load balancer VM on
locally with vagrant:

```
~/govuk/govuk-puppet $ vagrant up backend-lb-1.backend
```

Next, point the test domain to the running VM:

```
10.1.3.101 docs.dev.gov.uk
```

After this, visiting the docs will do the correct thing:

http://docs.dev.gov.uk/

subject: Bugfix Elasticsearch 2.4 install
message:
Bugfix Elasticsearch 2.4 install

  - the versioncmp function works rather than the regex (which didn't
  work as expected)
  - only install plugins for the older versions of elasticsearch. The
  Puppet module we're using for Elasticsearch is too old to install
  plugins on ES >2, so we can either fork the module, or install plugins
  manually until we've upgraded the old versions of Elasticsearch we're
  running.

subject: Start the Email Alert API production data earlier
message:
Start the Email Alert API production data earlier

This is to allow some additional buffer room for the production push to
complete before the staging pull (which I intend to make earlier too).

Currently this job is typically finishing at ~1:20am, which should move
this to around ~12:05am.

I'm planning to adjust the time of the pull from 3:10am until 1:30am to
reduce the chance this syncing clashes with the gor traffic replay.

```

message_without_subject:
This is to allow some additional buffer room for the production push to
complete before the staging pull (which I intend to make earlier too).

Currently this job is typically finishing at ~1:20am, which should move
this to around ~12:05am.

I'm planning to adjust the time of the pull from 3:10am until 1:30am to
reduce the chance this syncing clashes with the gor traffic replay.

subject: Proxy CSS and JS requests from main domain to assets domain
message:
Proxy CSS and JS requests from main domain to assets domain

This commit adds nginx configuration that allows CSS and JS files to be served under `www.gov.uk`, which will be proxied to `assets.publishing.service.gov.uk`. This helps with HTTP/2 performance since downloading CSS and JS files will no longer block requests for other assets.
message_without_subject: This commit adds nginx configuration that allows CSS and JS files to be served under `www.gov.uk`, which will be proxied to `assets.publishing.service.gov.uk`. This helps with HTTP/2 performance since downloading CSS and JS files will no longer block requests for other assets.

subject: Describe Okinawan as ryu-Jpan instead of ryu-Kana.
message:
Describe Okinawan as ryu-Jpan instead of ryu-Kana.

The main import of this is to affect the sample used by the web
site to illustrate Okinawan.  We don't have an Okinawan text sample
so use collections of characters based on the script.  Some
traditionalists use hiragana + kanji to write Okinawan according to
Wikipedia, so we just show the broader set based on Jpan instead of
restricting the set to Kana.

Wikipedia, so we just show the broader set based on Jpan instead of
restricting the set to Kana.

subject: upload: short circuit when nothing is pending
message:
upload: short circuit when nothing is pending

When nothing is pending, most of this code is already short-circuited.
Hoist the single check up to make this more obvious/slightly faster.

Change-Id: Iec3a7e08eacd23a7c5f964900d5776bf5252c804

subject: Allow callers of GitConfig to specify the pickle file path
message:
Allow callers of GitConfig to specify the pickle file path

This way we can put it in another directory than the config file
itself, e.g. hide it inside ".git" when parsing a ".gitmodules"
file from the working tree.

Signed-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <f3ea74d906fa9fe97c1fef6bad9cb871485c7045@google.com>

subject: Explicit about need for Jira Cloud for orb support
message:
Explicit about need for Jira Cloud for orb support

The orb integration to report build statuses depends on JWT tokens and Atlassian Connect, which is only available on their cloud offering. This is outside the control of CircleCI.

This change updates our docs to be explicit about this difference. Other features like "create an issue" will still work on server.

subject: Enhanced pdbtrack to provide for source code that's not findable by the reported path.  (Eg, precompiled scripts with a file path suitable for a different host, scripts actually running on a remote system or with no valid path, like Zope through-the-web python scripts.)
message:
Enhanced pdbtrack to provide for source code that's not findable by
the reported path.  (Eg, precompiled scripts with a file path suitable
for a different host, scripts actually running on a remote system or
with no valid path, like Zope through-the-web python scripts.)

On failing to find the code on the reported path, pdbtrack takes the
function name and looks through the buffers, from most to least
recent, seeking the first python-mode buffer that either is named for
the function or has a definition (def or class) for that function.  So
to get source tracking for code that's not located where the path
indicates, you put a copy of the script in a buffer, and pdbtrack will
find it.

Also, fixed a small bug so pdbtrack now properly presents the overlay
arrow when you run the pdb 'w'here command.
message_without_subject:
On failing to find the code on the reported path, pdbtrack takes the
function name and looks through the buffers, from most to least
recent, seeking the first python-mode buffer that either is named for
the function or has a definition (def or class) for that function.  So
to get source tracking for code that's not located where the path
indicates, you put a copy of the script in a buffer, and pdbtrack will
find it.

Also, fixed a small bug so pdbtrack now properly presents the overlay
arrow when you run the pdb 'w'here command.

subject: Start with isLEDChanged set
message:
Start with isLEDChanged set

If we start with isLEDChanged unset, then after flashing, the `R0C0` key will
remain lit, because we think it is off, while it is not. Setting this flag
results in the first update cycle updating everything, no matter what, which is
the safest thing we can do.

Signed-off-by: Gergely Nagy <6780fac3b38619ac20422286e4110a70dbba2203@madhouse-project.org>
message_without_subject:
If we start with isLEDChanged unset, then after flashing, the `R0C0` key will
remain lit, because we think it is off, while it is not. Setting this flag
results in the first update cycle updating everything, no matter what, which is
the safest thing we can do.

subject: userscripts: fix FIFO on Windows
message:
userscripts: fix FIFO on Windows

The userscript FIFO on Windows suffered the same problem that open-editor
once did, because files on Windows can't be opened with write access by
two different processes. We kept the oshandle around and only closed it
when the process exited, which means that userscripts could not actually
write any commands to the FIFO.

This patch closes the file earlier, allowing the userscript to actually
write commands to it.

See also
https://lists.schokokeks.org/pipermail/qutebrowser/2016-September/000256.html
message_without_subject:
The userscript FIFO on Windows suffered the same problem that open-editor
once did, because files on Windows can't be opened with write access by
two different processes. We kept the oshandle around and only closed it
when the process exited, which means that userscripts could not actually
write any commands to the FIFO.

This patch closes the file earlier, allowing the userscript to actually
write commands to it.

See also
https://lists.schokokeks.org/pipermail/qutebrowser/2016-September/000256.html

subject: Don't emit predicted_navigation when reloading because of it
message:
Don't emit predicted_navigation when reloading because of it

When we reload because of a config change in _on_load_finished, we can't use
self.reload() as no URL is set yet. Instead, we call self.openurl with the
current URL.

However, we need to make sure we don't emit predicted_navigation again at that
point.

This should (finally) fix #3718

subject: Enable External UI Support
message:
Enable External UI Support

This adds support for an external UI with zero access to the core access.
All access is done through OSC messages which can be either on a local or remote
machine, though there may be some minor cases where they depend on struct
packing due to shoving stuff into blobs.
There doesn't seem to be any lag given that both sides consume all events when
they check for them and when running with a large amount of latency elements
still appear to be correct in the end.

This does add some regressions in the controls which did depend upon direct
access, such as the ConfigUI, PresetUI, and NioUI, however those should be fixed
to use the OSC API anyhow. Some new widget types will be made for these cases
and the vision of everything over OSC will be obtained.

subject: Inrease the Trap size of the truncated packet while Trapping to Agent
message:
Inrease the Trap size of the truncated packet while Trapping to Agent

Currently for certain Trap messages the packet is trncated to 128 bytes.
if the packet is truncated to 128 bytes, Agent does not get to see the
transport header depending on the encapsulation of the packet. The
ICMP packet being received with Vxlan encap  is one such scenario where
Vrouter creates a flow with right Transport ports but as Agent does not
see the correct ports it handles that as different flow. This leads to
Hold entries being left in Vrouter.

To avoid this, instead of using the standard 128 bytes as Truncation, it
is calculated using the headers length.

Change-Id: Ifba2e7af4f1eb2310593a14a81350446273b2875
closes-bug: #1588623
message_without_subject:
Currently for certain Trap messages the packet is trncated to 128 bytes.
if the packet is truncated to 128 bytes, Agent does not get to see the
transport header depending on the encapsulation of the packet. The
ICMP packet being received with Vxlan encap  is one such scenario where
Vrouter creates a flow with right Transport ports but as Agent does not
see the correct ports it handles that as different flow. This leads to
Hold entries being left in Vrouter.

To avoid this, instead of using the standard 128 bytes as Truncation, it
is calculated using the headers length.

Change-Id: Ifba2e7af4f1eb2310593a14a81350446273b2875
closes-bug: #1588623

subject: base_kmem/test_basic.sh: Use integer division instead of multiplication in count check
message:
base_kmem/test_basic.sh: Use integer division instead of multiplication in count check

In case the result gets floored, the multiplication causes the test to fail:
206 / 3 == 68 (remainder 2)
However, 3 * 68 != 206.

Changing multiplication to integer division fixes that problem.

However, the condition needed another (), since before this commit, it was:

  if (regexp_met and equation1 or equation2)

Due to that, equation2 was evaluated even if !regexp_met, which was a hidden
problem in case of multiplication, but with division, in case the regexp didn't
match, equation2 evaluation failed on division by zero.

Changing it to:

  if (regexp_met and (equation1 or equation2))

... fixes the problem, since if !regexp_met, the equations are not evaluated.
message_without_subject:
In case the result gets floored, the multiplication causes the test to fail:
206 / 3 == 68 (remainder 2)
However, 3 * 68 != 206.

Changing multiplication to integer division fixes that problem.

However, the condition needed another (), since before this commit, it was:

Due to that, equation2 was evaluated even if !regexp_met, which was a hidden
problem in case of multiplication, but with division, in case the regexp didn't
match, equation2 evaluation failed on division by zero.

Changing it to:

  if (regexp_met and (equation1 or equation2))

... fixes the problem, since if !regexp_met, the equations are not evaluated.

subject: Manually add the automatically installed libraries to this branch
message:
Manually add the automatically installed libraries to this branch

We can then use this as the base for the branches that we want to deploy to
ionic.

So in order to deploy a new channel, we:
- checkout a new, temporary branch from this one
- merge the branch to deploy into the temp branch
- commit and push to ionic
- delete the temp branch

These changes (to add the new libraries installed from bower) should never be
merged into master. Also, if we have a separate template for deployable code,
we can delete the habitica avatar stuff from it instead of from each of the
branches, which will make the branches much easier to use because they won't
have this big honking diff from master.

subject: Remove NULL bytes from text messages
message:
Remove NULL bytes from text messages

They are likely to trip up many things later,
including our own C-based Markdown-to-HTML convertor.

Normally, we don't expect people to be entering NULL bytes in
messages, but because of a bug in iOS 11, it's easy to have it happen.

iOS 11's Smart Punctuation feature "conveniently" converts double
hyphens (`--`) to longer en-dashes (`—`).
However, when adding any kind of dash/hyphen after such an
en-dash, iOS would also insert a NULL byte inbetween the dashes
(`<en-dash>NULL<some other dash>`).

Even if a future iOS update fixes this, we'd better be defensive
and always remove occurrences of NULL bytes from text messages.

Signed-off-by: Slavi Pantaleev <018f1c5d0b0446d0b5f0fcc3b1fe8269e0d0200a@gmail.com>
message_without_subject:

subject: libc/minimal: reallocarray() in terms of realloc()
message:
libc/minimal: reallocarray() in terms of realloc()

reallocarray() is defined in terms of realloc(). From OpenBSD manual
pages:
    "Designed for safe allocation of arrays, the reallocarray()
    function is similar to realloc() except it operates on nmemb
    members of size size and checks for integer overflow in the
    calculation nmemb * size."

The return value of sys_heap_realloc() is not compatible with that
of realloc().

Signed-off-by: Martin Åberg <37424e7fbe3f8590d57db5ed6ae5b8866742b6be@gaisler.com>
message_without_subject:
reallocarray() is defined in terms of realloc(). From OpenBSD manual

subject: drivers: hwinfo: fix build with NEWLIB_LIBC=y
message:
drivers: hwinfo: fix build with NEWLIB_LIBC=y

When NEWLIB_LIBC=y, building the hwinfo drivers fails with:

In file included from ZEPHYR_ROOT/drivers/hwinfo/hwinfo_weak_impl.c:7:0:
ZEPHYR_ROOT/include/hwinfo.h:43:1: error: unknown type name '__syscall';
did you mean '__fastcall'?
 __syscall ssize_t hwinfo_get_device_id(u8_t *buffer, size_t length);
 ^~~~~~~~~
 __fastcall
ZEPHYR_ROOT/include/hwinfo.h:43:19: error: expected '=', ',', ';', 'asm'
or '__attribute__' before 'hwinfo_get_device_id'
 __syscall ssize_t hwinfo_get_device_id(u8_t *buffer, size_t length);
                   ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
ZEPHYR_ROOT/drivers/hwinfo/hwinfo_weak_impl.c:9:16: error: expected '=',
',', ';', 'asm' or '__attribute__' before '_impl_hwinfo_get_device_id'
 ssize_t __weak _impl_hwinfo_get_device_id(u8_t *buffer, size_t length)
                ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.

The <hwinfo.h> file uses __syscall and this symbols is defined by
<kernel.h>. This doesn't happen with the real drivers as they include
<device.h> and thus <kernel.h>.

Fix that by including <kernel.h> from <hwinfo.h>

Signed-off-by: Aurelien Jarno <bceb368e7f2cb351af47298f32034f0587bbe4a6@aurel32.net>
message_without_subject:
When NEWLIB_LIBC=y, building the hwinfo drivers fails with:

In file included from ZEPHYR_ROOT/drivers/hwinfo/hwinfo_weak_impl.c:7:0:
ZEPHYR_ROOT/include/hwinfo.h:43:1: error: unknown type name '__syscall';
did you mean '__fastcall'?

 ^~~~~~~~~
 __fastcall
ZEPHYR_ROOT/include/hwinfo.h:43:19: error: expected '=', ',', ';', 'asm'
or '__attribute__' before 'hwinfo_get_device_id'

                   ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
ZEPHYR_ROOT/drivers/hwinfo/hwinfo_weak_impl.c:9:16: error: expected '=',
',', ';', 'asm' or '__attribute__' before '_impl_hwinfo_get_device_id'
 ssize_t __weak _impl_hwinfo_get_device_id(u8_t *buffer, size_t length)
                ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.

The <hwinfo.h> file uses __syscall and this symbols is defined by

<device.h> and thus <kernel.h>.

Fix that by including <kernel.h> from <hwinfo.h>

subject: net: Do not send ICMP error if dst address is multicast one
message:
net: Do not send ICMP error if dst address is multicast one

If we have received IPv6 or IPv4 packet where destination
address is a multicast one, and if there is no connection
listener for that address, then do not send ICMP destination
unreachable port error to peer.

message:
boards: stm32: argonkey: Add dts support to sensors

This patch adds dts support to lps22hb/hts221/vl53l0x
I2C sensors as well as lsm6dsl SPI sensor.

Since some info, like gpio for irq triggering or SPI bus
characteristics, may be provided through dts, they need
to be made optional in the LSM6DSL driver by usage of
macros like HAS_DTS_SPI_PINS or HAS_DTS_SPI_DEVICE.

subject: build: simplfy how extra build steps are specified
message:
build: simplfy how extra build steps are specified

For various reasons its often necessary to generate certain
complex data structures at build-time by separate tools outside
of the C compiler. Data is populated to these tools by way of
special binary sections not intended to be included in the final
binary. We currently do this to generate interrupt tables, forthcoming
work will also use this to generate MMU page tables.

The way we have been doing this is to generatea "kernel_prebuilt.elf",
extract the metadata sections with objcopy, run the tool, and then
re-link the kernel with the extra data *and* use objcopy to pull
out the unwanted sections.

This doesn't scale well if multiple post-build steps are needed.
Now this is much simpler; in any Makefile, a special
GENERATED_KERNEL_OBJECT_FILES variable may be appended to containing
the filenames to the generated object files, which will be generated
by Make in the usual fashion.

Instead of using objcopy to pull out, we now create a linker-pass2.cmd
which additionally defines LINKER_PASS2. The source linker script
can #ifdef around this to use the special /DISCARD/ section target
to not include metadata sections in the final binary.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Boie <aab045b28152628be6af0e556050d0381fd0a34d@intel.com>
message_without_subject:
For various reasons its often necessary to generate certain
complex data structures at build-time by separate tools outside
of the C compiler. Data is populated to these tools by way of
special binary sections not intended to be included in the final
binary. We currently do this to generate interrupt tables, forthcoming
work will also use this to generate MMU page tables.

The way we have been doing this is to generatea "kernel_prebuilt.elf",
extract the metadata sections with objcopy, run the tool, and then
re-link the kernel with the extra data *and* use objcopy to pull
out the unwanted sections.

This doesn't scale well if multiple post-build steps are needed.
Now this is much simpler; in any Makefile, a special
GENERATED_KERNEL_OBJECT_FILES variable may be appended to containing
the filenames to the generated object files, which will be generated

Instead of using objcopy to pull out, we now create a linker-pass2.cmd
which additionally defines LINKER_PASS2. The source linker script
can #ifdef around this to use the special /DISCARD/ section target
to not include metadata sections in the final binary.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Boie <aab045b28152628be6af0e556050d0381fd0a34d@intel.com>

subject: Bluetooth: monitor: Drop data instead of holding IRQ lock for long
message:
Bluetooth: monitor: Drop data instead of holding IRQ lock for long

The IRQ lock should never be held for long periods of time. Instead of
using the IRQ lock to prevent monitor protocol corruption simply drop
the data. Follow-up patches will add additional drop count tracking so
that these get reported properly over the protocol.

Change-Id: If498125b29f1b58bed676c78ad2062e2aa206318
Signed-off-by: Johan Hedberg <628991c7b0a19c384f9b99c21ec330ce952bb838@intel.com>

using the IRQ lock to prevent monitor protocol corruption simply drop
the data. Follow-up patches will add additional drop count tracking so

subject: cmake: use sdk-ng built toolchain for x86_64
message:
cmake: use sdk-ng built toolchain for x86_64

This adds the necessary bits to utilize the x86_64 toolchain
built by sdk-ng for x86_64 when toolchain variant is either
zephyr or xtools. This allows decoupling the builds from
the host toolchain.

Newlib is also available with this toolchain so remove
the Kconfig restriction on CONFIG_NEWLIB_LIBC.

subject: doc: flatten doxygen-generated HTML structure
message:
doc: flatten doxygen-generated HTML structure

The current doxygen configuration settings create 4096 folders to hold
the generated HTML output (with names such as d3/ddb/).  This makes it
difficult to know what an URL would be for a particular module's
(defgroup's) documentation.  By not creating these subdirectories,
module documentation file names become quite predictable:

     group__<group name>.html

(e.g., group__sensor__interface.html) allowing us to create
links from the Sphinx-generated documentation into the doxygen-generated
HTML content (this part is under investigation).

Signed-off-by: David B. Kinder <c56c8b29908a5b2af1b63001268d73a0b7f972ba@intel.com>
message_without_subject:

subject: Introduce cmake-based rewrite of KBuild
message:
Introduce cmake-based rewrite of KBuild

Introducing CMake is an important step in a larger effort to make
Zephyr easy to use for application developers working on different
platforms with different development environment needs.

Simplified, this change retains Kconfig as-is, and replaces all
Makefiles with CMakeLists.txt. The DSL-like Make language that KBuild
offers is replaced by a set of CMake extentions. These extentions have
either provided simple one-to-one translations of KBuild features or
introduced new concepts that replace KBuild concepts.

This is a breaking change for existing test infrastructure and build
scripts that are maintained out-of-tree. But for FW itself, no porting
should be necessary.

For users that just want to continue their work with minimal
disruption the following should suffice:

Install CMake 3.8.2+

Port any out-of-tree Makefiles to CMake.

Learn the absolute minimum about the new command line interface:

$ cd samples/hello_world
$ mkdir build && cd build
$ cmake -DBOARD=nrf52_pca10040 ..

$ cd build
$ make

PR: zephyrproject-rtos#4692
docs: http://docs.zephyrproject.org/getting_started/getting_started.html

Signed-off-by: Sebastian Boe <edee888afd63e94916688495334700803eba20a0@nordicsemi.no>
message_without_subject:

subject: arc: remove defaults for IRQ priority levels
message:
arc: remove defaults for IRQ priority levels

The deleted defaults cannot be overriden by defaults defined
in SoC's Kconfig file. The number of IRQ priority level was
always one, and this caused some code to be dropped within
the fast IRQ handling code. When the electrons aligned in
certain way, undesired effects were observed (e.g. exception,
faults, etc.) when regular IRQs were mixed with fast IRQs.

Moreover, ARC cores are high configurable on hardware level.
So let the SoC config define these values instead.

Change-Id: I2a338d2efc814c46b0f68ab100fc0f66ae0fb60c
Signed-off-by: Daniel Leung <d94e04d205b5962d7873a139ef298b03c1717f72@intel.com>
message_without_subject:
The deleted defaults cannot be overriden by defaults defined
in SoC's Kconfig file. The number of IRQ priority level was
always one, and this caused some code to be dropped within
the fast IRQ handling code. When the electrons aligned in
certain way, undesired effects were observed (e.g. exception,
faults, etc.) when regular IRQs were mixed with fast IRQs.

Moreover, ARC cores are high configurable on hardware level.
So let the SoC config define these values instead.

Change-Id: I2a338d2efc814c46b0f68ab100fc0f66ae0fb60c
Signed-off-by: Daniel Leung <d94e04d205b5962d7873a139ef298b03c1717f72@intel.com>

subject: crypto: Update TinyCrypt to 0.2.7
message:
crypto: Update TinyCrypt to 0.2.7

Version 0.2.7 of this library has been released on June 30th, and this
patch updates the library from version 0.2.6.  A summary of changes
is available at the official repository at:

    https://github.com/01org/tinycrypt/releases/tag/v0.2.7

There were some API changes in this version, so some tests are not
building: ccm_mode, ecc_dh, and ecc_dsa.  Fixes to these tests and
subsystems affected by the changes will be provided.

subject: Use SoC instead of platform.
message:

Change terminology and use SoC instead of platform. An SoC provides
features and default configurations available with an SoC. A board
implements the SoC and adds more features and IP block specific to the
board to extend the SoC functionality such as sensors and debugging
features.

subject: tests/lib: Add sys_heap test
message:
tests/lib: Add sys_heap test

Use the white box validation and test rig added as part of the
sys_heap work.  Add a layer that puts hashed cookies into the blocks
to detect corruption, check the validity state after every operation,
and enumerate a few different usage patterns:

+ Small heap, "real world" allocation where the heap is about half
full and most allocations succeed.

+ Small heap, "fragmentation runaway" scenario where most allocations
start failing, but the heap must remain consistent.

+ Big heap.  We can't test this with the same exhaustive coverage
(many re/allocations for every byte of storage) for performance
reasons, but we do what we can.

Signed-off-by: Andy Ross <c70f9a6bf6ee0cd69c8af4ce5e6b131945769315@intel.com>
message_without_subject:
Use the white box validation and test rig added as part of the
sys_heap work.  Add a layer that puts hashed cookies into the blocks
to detect corruption, check the validity state after every operation,

subject: cmake: fix DTS handling of multiple overlay files
message:
cmake: fix DTS handling of multiple overlay files

This commit fixes an issue where providing a list of overlay files for
dts was not handled correctly.
The means that using `-DDTC_OVERLAY_FILE="file1.overlay;file2.overlay"`
would fail as those two file names would be concatenated into a single
file name.

This is fixed by properly quote the `DTC_OVERLAY_FILE` variable.

Signed-off-by: Torsten Rasmussen <a7c5b1d5a1f41fce6edfa3f7c2392ae0c59deafe@nordicsemi.no>
message_without_subject:
This commit fixes an issue where providing a list of overlay files for
dts was not handled correctly.
The means that using `-DDTC_OVERLAY_FILE="file1.overlay;file2.overlay"`
would fail as those two file names would be concatenated into a single
file name.

This is fixed by properly quote the `DTC_OVERLAY_FILE` variable.

Signed-off-by: Torsten Rasmussen <a7c5b1d5a1f41fce6edfa3f7c2392ae0c59deafe@nordicsemi.no>

subject: drivers: eth: gmac: Enable 802.1Qav support
message:
drivers: eth: gmac: Enable 802.1Qav support

This commit makes the driver enable HW Qav support for all available
priority queues.

Note that the hardware doesn't support setting the deltaBandwidth
parameter directly, but it is possible to do this by calculating it
from the negotiated link speed.

The default settings are set according to 802.1Qav 34.3.1, that says:

  The recommended default value of deltaBandwidth(N) for the highest
  numbered traffic class supported is 75%, and for any lower
  numbered traffic classes, the recommended default value is 0%.

The default/recommended values can be changed using the ethernet
management API (set_config) - which this commit also adds.

Signed-off-by: Tomasz Gorochowik <265c7c25eca9aa9127910457b0aea7e793d329f1@antmicro.com>
message_without_subject:
This commit makes the driver enable HW Qav support for all available

subject: posix: time.h: Add workaround for outdated newlib used by Xtensa
message:
posix: time.h: Add workaround for outdated newlib used by Xtensa

Unfortunately, Zephyr SDK 0.10.0 ships with outdated Newlib 2.0.0
(from 2015 or earlier) which lacks sys/_timespec.h header, requiring
ugly workaround of defining struct timespec inline (the whole idea
was to standardize on sys/_timespec.h header for different libc's).

This is similar to earlier workaround for struct timeval definition
introduced in a6aee9b4c85642053d. Zephyr SDK ticket for this issue
is https://github.com/zephyrproject-rtos/sdk-ng/issues/64, and it
will ve possible to remove both workarounds when Xtensa toolchain
will be upgraded to newlib version consistent with other
architectures.

Signed-off-by: Paul Sokolovsky <35cb557f011771c94f127d6fef99f804b62203f5@linaro.org>
message_without_subject:
Unfortunately, Zephyr SDK 0.10.0 ships with outdated Newlib 2.0.0
(from 2015 or earlier) which lacks sys/_timespec.h header, requiring
ugly workaround of defining struct timespec inline (the whole idea
was to standardize on sys/_timespec.h header for different libc's).

This is similar to earlier workaround for struct timeval definition
introduced in a6aee9b4c85642053d. Zephyr SDK ticket for this issue
is https://github.com/zephyrproject-rtos/sdk-ng/issues/64, and it
will ve possible to remove both workarounds when Xtensa toolchain
will be upgraded to newlib version consistent with other
architectures.

Signed-off-by: Paul Sokolovsky <35cb557f011771c94f127d6fef99f804b62203f5@linaro.org>

message:
unified/doc: Update ring buffers section of Kernel Primer

Ring buffer section now resides under "other" topic, since the
ring buffer type is a general purpose type (like the singly and
doubly linked list types), rather than a kernel-specific type.

Enhances ring buffer section to improve content and improve
consistency with the form used elsewhere in the Kernel Primer.

Also corrects a minor error in the ring buffer API documentation.

subject: BREAKING Scraper: Put burden of sorting search results on the scraper plugin
message:
BREAKING Scraper: Put burden of sorting search results on the scraper plugin

Because the identified metadata is not guaranteed to return the game title, nor is the scraper plugin obligated to use such data, it is up to the scraper plugin to determine which game is the best match for the game. Plugins may use whatever metadata is available to them to order the list.
message_without_subject: Because the identified metadata is not guaranteed to return the game title, nor is the scraper plugin obligated to use such data, it is up to the scraper plugin to determine which game is the best match for the game. Plugins may use whatever metadata is available to them to order the list.

subject: Make branding type non-nullable
message:
Make branding type non-nullable

We’ve already removed all the `null` values, and made it impossible to
add new brandings with a `null` brand type.

Making it a database constraint just gives us extra safety.
message_without_subject:
We’ve already removed all the `null` values, and made it impossible to

subject: move get_pdf functionality to its own endpoint
message:
move get_pdf functionality to its own endpoint

it felt very awkward when the body of a pdf might be empty, might have
things in it, and whether it is empty or not can change even when the
status is the same (a created template notification might have a pdf,
but might not, we don't know).

So move it to its own endpoint, so we can hand craft some 400 errors
that appropriately explain what's going on.

subject: Webpack4 - emit webpack runtime chunk only in the vendor bundle, not in every one
message:
Webpack4 - emit webpack runtime chunk only in the vendor bundle, not in every one

without this, when the same file is included from multiple packs (webpack entrypoints), it will get run separately for each

this is because each bundle has its own copy of the webpack runtime, which deals with this "has it run yet" logic

this change causes the webpack runtime to only be emitted once, and shared by the other packs

thus, multiple imports of the same package should run it only once again, regardless of whether this happens within one pack or accross multiple packs
message_without_subject:
without this, when the same file is included from multiple packs (webpack entrypoints), it will get run separately for each

this is because each bundle has its own copy of the webpack runtime, which deals with this "has it run yet" logic

this change causes the webpack runtime to only be emitted once, and shared by the other packs

thus, multiple imports of the same package should run it only once again, regardless of whether this happens within one pack or accross multiple packs

subject: Introduce XML declared constraints for preferences.
message:
Introduce XML declared constraints for preferences.

Different features require different API levels or are limited to
certain admins and users. Previously, each fragment would maintain a
list of preferences to restrict under certain conditions and had to
disable those preferences  when the fragment loaded. Moving these
constraints into the XML is a simpler and more declarative approach.

Change-Id: I56ab4581efeba192d3b24794f1b35304ac137ebe
message_without_subject:
Different features require different API levels or are limited to
certain admins and users. Previously, each fragment would maintain a

constraints into the XML is a simpler and more declarative approach.

Change-Id: I56ab4581efeba192d3b24794f1b35304ac137ebe

subject: Set/unset node's target RAID config via OSC command
message:
Set/unset node's target RAID config via OSC command

Allows setting and unsetting (clearing) the node's target
RAID configuration via the OpenStackClient plugin commands
'openstack baremetal node set --target-raid-config' and
'openstack baremetal node unset --target-raid-config'
respectively.

Change-Id: I5ee61aec4d110a84d50347fa10b7c16fc2fda353
Partial-Bug: #1526479

subject: Allow providing --ssh-user for update/upgrade run commands
message:
Allow providing --ssh-user for update/upgrade run commands

When config-download becomes our only way of deploying, we'll be able
to assume that tripleo-admin user always exists. Until then it's not a
given, so we need to allow using custom user names for running updates
and upgrades playbooks. We default to heat-admin for now, as that's
expected to work on majority of current production environments.

Change-Id: I0df57002b2305c1e2504c9f7a7d0c326d8ffcaf7
Closes-Bug: #1759845
message_without_subject:

subject: Do not log plugins & setup scripts
message:
Do not log plugins & setup scripts

The redirects used with exec requires them to run under /bin/bash which
breaks the templating in setup.sh. They currently specify /bin/sh which
on Ubuntu stemcells is symlinked to /bin/dash. I don't know what exactly
/bin/sh is on CentOS stemcells, or whether setup.sh even works on
anything other than /bin/dash, but we know with certainty that it breaks
in /bin/bash.

For now, we are running these scripts as commands, not by sourcing them
in subshells, since the rabbitmq-server.init /bin/bash runtime will
overwrite any she-bang they specify.

We are also seeing that plugins.sh is actually failing because the
Erlang VM is not running, even though the plugins which it is trying to
enable are already enabled. Running `rabbitmqctl status` shows that all
3 apps/plugins are enabled and running: mqtt, stomp &
rabbitmq_management, in spite of these failures.

[#124356151]

Signed-off-by: Gerhard Lazu <1dbacecb153173531fe28399d2eb60d6542a913b@pivotal.io>
message_without_subject:

For now, we are running these scripts as commands, not by sourcing them

subject: Demo
message:
Demo

- ScrollIntoViewDemo. This is preparation for CUI's scrollIntoView support.

Template

- Reworked Template base system: Don't keep template nodes inside the Live DOM.
  When using Template.loadFile, don't insert these nodes into DOM. If your
  HTML has Templates, use Template.load to collect (and remove) them from Live DOM.
message_without_subject:
- ScrollIntoViewDemo. This is preparation for CUI's scrollIntoView support.

Template

- Reworked Template base system: Don't keep template nodes inside the Live DOM.
  When using Template.loadFile, don't insert these nodes into DOM. If your
  HTML has Templates, use Template.load to collect (and remove) them from Live DOM.

subject: Make the SchedulingManager more BASE design friendly
message:
Make the SchedulingManager more BASE design friendly

Running the SchedulingManager concurrently (in different processes) leads to parallel repair runs being spawned at the same time.

This has been implemented by
 - making reads and writes to repair_schedule table strictly consistent (quorum),
 - updating (writes to storage) the repair_schedule incremently in the SchedulingManager.manageSchedule(..) codepath, and
 - multiple checks (reads from storage) through the same codepath.

 ref: https://github.com/thelastpickle/cassandra-reaper/pull/124
message_without_subject:

 - multiple checks (reads from storage) through the same codepath.

 ref: https://github.com/thelastpickle/cassandra-reaper/pull/124

subject: When there are no broadcasters and no known subscriptions, only check for updated events once per minute
message:
When there are no broadcasters and no known subscriptions, only check for updated events once per minute

This will reduce table scans on diagnostic_event_subscription when reaper is distributed and diagnostics not otherwise used/subscribed to.
Based off findings from https://github.com/thelastpickle/cassandra-reaper/issues/896

subject: Scripts/Commands: Fix guid usage and enhance commands (#18278)
message:
Scripts/Commands: Fix guid usage and enhance commands (#18278)

- Fix targeting gameobjects and creatures for .dist and .gps. The old code used DB guid to search from core generated guid lists.
- Fix some error messages saying 'no player found' even if creatures and gameobjects and players were searched
- Change atoi to atoul when receiving lowguids as string or other uint32 values
- Use ObjectGuid::LowType instead of uint32 for lowguid type
- Allow .gob info to take in gameobject guid link as well as entry link in addition to gameobject entry and update the documentation of the command
- Change .gob delete to post the spawnid (dbguid) instead of the ingame generated guid (which is basically never seen or used by the player in any other commands that I see)
- Allow spawntimesecs to be negative when spawning a gameobject
- Disable searching by ingame spawn id in commands. (it makes little sense for a user to provide a number which is then attempted to be used as DB guid and non DB guid when both could have a match)
- Update .gob turn documentation to tell about possibility to provide orientation in command
- Correct the types in .gob add command result trinity_string
- Correct the creature search for .npc del
- Change .event to .event info
- Add .go offset command
- Remove the .go command for empty string (no subcommand given) because it just used .go xyz
- Extend .gob info to show size, faction, flags and model dimensions
- Remove some unnecessary casts
- Document .wp show better (first and last were not documented)
- Insert spawnid to .wp show info error message
- Fix spawntime printing for .gobject target
- Fix guid targetting for .npc set movetype
- Fix query by spawnid for .wp show info
- Fix deleting of existing waypoints when twice doing the command .wp show on
- Fix deleting of existing waypoints when doing the command .wp show off
- Change wpguid column in DB and in core to uint32, which is what the spawnid type is in core and db.

- Use ObjectGuid::LowType instead of uint32 for lowguid type

- Change .gob delete to post the spawnid (dbguid) instead of the ingame generated guid (which is basically never seen or used by the player in any other commands that I see)
- Allow spawntimesecs to be negative when spawning a gameobject
- Disable searching by ingame spawn id in commands. (it makes little sense for a user to provide a number which is then attempted to be used as DB guid and non DB guid when both could have a match)
- Update .gob turn documentation to tell about possibility to provide orientation in command
- Correct the types in .gob add command result trinity_string
- Correct the creature search for .npc del
- Change .event to .event info
- Add .go offset command
- Remove the .go command for empty string (no subcommand given) because it just used .go xyz

subject: [Quest] Kodo Roundup
message:
[Quest] Kodo Roundup

by @pete318, closes #12811

Fixes the remaining bugs in the "Kodo Roundup" quest in Desolace:
- removes combat status from creature 11627, Tamed Kodo
- sets normal walking speed as the creature's follow speed
- makes the Tamed Kodo stop at Scrabblescrew's Camp
- enables quest objective count 0/5 -> 5/5, quest complete
- SQL (by @tkrokli) links the missing gossip text in the DB

subject: Make TopicMenuSelectWidget clip correctly
message:
Make TopicMenuSelectWidget clip correctly

Instead of forcing the clippable container to be the wrapper
like 2b8f2fede7 did (which had problems: the menu wouldn't
clip to the window, so you could get it to run off the bottom
of the window), let the clippable container be the body
and set up the CSS to make that work:

* Remove the overflow: hidden; rule on the wrapper.
* Remove the max-height on the menu, but keep it on the wrapper.
* Set overflow-y: auto; on the menu for when it's not clipping
  (when it is clipping, overflow-y: auto; is already set in
  inline style by ClippableElement).

Bonus: remove the min-width rule because it doesn't do anything useful.

Change-Id: Icc0f05ce869e0f2d903a1f7ae213c27b2f9675ee

subject: Fix typo in AbstractDateFilter which can lead to exceptions
message:
Fix typo in AbstractDateFilter which can lead to exceptions

v3.15. introduced a bug because of a type in AbstractDateFilter, referencing Sonata\AdminBundle\Form\Type\Operator\DateRangeOperatorType::TYPE_EQUAL, where it should have been Sonata\AdminBundle\Form\Type\Operator\DateOperatorType::TYPE_EQUAL.

subject: Exclude README and CONTRIBUTING from automatic HTML conversion
message:
Exclude README and CONTRIBUTING from automatic HTML conversion

When running `make` to generate the HTML version of the site, all
Markdown files are automatically found and converted - including
README.md and CONTRIBUTING.md.

These two aren't really wanted, and the resulting HTML versions need to
be ignored or deleted. It's not sufficient to add them to .gitignore,
because they'll still be there in the filesystem causing confusion, even
if the risk of committing them to Git is minimized.

This change filters them out of the Makefile's argument list of Markdown
files that should be automatically converted to HTML, so the unwanted
versions don't get generated in the first place.

Before:

```
$ make
pandoc -f markdown-smart+autolink_bare_uris --template index.tmpl CONTRIBUTING.md -o CONTRIBUTING.html
pandoc -f markdown-smart+autolink_bare_uris --template index.tmpl README.md -o README.html
```

After:

```
$ make
make: Nothing to be done for 'all'.
```

```

After:

```

make: Nothing to be done for 'all'.
```
